data.title: 5 Best Stocks That Can Rise Above Trump Tariffs And Macro Uncertainty
data.description:
Select AI Stocks and Metals Miners Gain Amid Tariff Shifts

Trade policy has returned to the center of the investment landscape, but so has the opportunity for stock pickers to look beyond the headlines. The Supreme Court’s recent decision reshaping tariff authority, followed by the implementation of a new tariff framework, has created both risks and opportunities across global markets.

At the same time, the broader 2026 macro backdrop remains defined by lingering inflation pressures, uneven economic growth, and geopolitical tension. These conditions resemble a mild stagflationary environment. Historically, these periods reward industries and companies tied to hard assets, supply chain resilience, and structural growth themes. Meanwhile, the secular buildout of artificial intelligence infrastructure continues largely undeterred, creating a powerful counterbalance to macro uncertainty.

5-Day Performance: XLK vs GDX vs SPY

Beneficiaries of trade policy and macro uncertainty, such as gold miners (GDX), are seeing a return of strength, while the tech sector (XLK) has held up amid volatility and has strong long-term growth potential. For investors, the result is a market where some companies benefit directly from trade policy shifts while others gain indirectly through capital rotation, commodity strength, or continued technology investment. The most compelling opportunities now appear in areas ranging from precious metals to dominant platforms and key suppliers within the AI ecosystem. This adheres to my recent themes of diversification and use of the barbell strategy for 2026.

What Is the Barbell Strategy of Investing?

A barbell strategy balances exposure between defensive assets and high-growth opportunities to navigate uncertain markets. In the current macro backdrop of tariffs, geopolitical tension, and persistent AI investment, I’m proposing a mix of stocks that reflect that approach. For example, precious metals producers provide protection during inflationary or risk-off periods, while platform and semiconductor companies offer participation in long-term technology expansion. Together, the combination allows investors to maintain resilience against volatility while still capturing upside forward growth potential.

How I Chose the Best Stocks to Buy Now

This group of five stocks was selected by using a range of preselected categories found on the main Seeking Alpha Stock Screener page. I searched the Top Materials Stocks screen and sorted by industry to target gold miners. I did a similar search for Top Technology Stocks, as well as Top Consumer Discretionary Stocks. I then targeted Quant Strong Buys with an attractive combination of Quant Factor Grades in Valuation, Growth, Profitability, Momentum, and Revisions.

1. Barrick Mining (B)

  • Market Capitalization: $83.45B

  • Quant Rating: Strong Buy

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 15 out of 280

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 8 out of 48

  • Sector: Materials

  • Industry: Gold

Barrick Mining is one of the world’s largest gold producers, operating major mines across North America and several international jurisdictions. In an environment shaped by tariffs, geopolitical tension, and inflation concerns, gold often attracts investors seeking stability. That dynamic can amplify the earnings leverage of large miners, particularly those with strong balance sheets following large run-ups in the price of gold. Barrick’s scale and relatively low-cost operations magnify these benefits, especially if investors continue to use gold as a safe haven hedge against economic uncertainty. Setting up the fundamental strengths, I’ll begin with Barrick’s valuation metrics.

Barrick’s forward non-GAAP P/E of 13.55 offers nearly a 20% discount to sector peers, while its PEG, which factors in the miner’s forward growth potential, is even more attractive at 0.30, offering almost a 77% discount to peers. Supporting the attractive PEG is Barrick’s stellar growth metrics, which earn it an ‘A’ for its respective Quant Factor grade. The miner’s forward EBITDA growth is nearly 4x the sector median, while its free cash flow per share rate of nearly 72% is more than 4.5X its sector peers. These metrics signal that Barrick Mining is entering a period where rising gold prices and operational efficiency are translating into material future profitability and cash generation. This gives the company greater capacity to fund dividends, reduce debt, and reinvest in high-return projects.

Geopolitical tensions and tariff-driven economic uncertainty can continue to support gold prices in 2026, which can translate into free cash flow for miners, which helps explain renewed interest in this space. My next stock, another precious metals company, offers a different angle on that same theme.

2. Coeur Mining, Inc. (CDE)

  • Market Capitalization: $15.79B

  • Quant Rating: Strong Buy

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 2 out of 280

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 2 out of 48

  • Sector: Materials

  • Industry: Gold

Coeur Mining is a U.S.-based precious metals miner that provides a complement to Barrick by adding silver exposure and higher operating leverage. Like Barrick, CDE's hard asset connection can work well in a macro environment shaped by tariff uncertainty, geopolitical tension, and stagflationary pressures. While large miners provide stability, mid-tier names like Coeur tend to respond more quickly to rising metal prices, and the stock has been a member of the flagship Alpha Picks portfolio since Sept. 15, 2025, and returned 52%-plus to the portfolio. Therefore, Coeur Mining becomes more compelling if gold continues acting as a macro hedge while silver benefits from industrial usage tied to electrification trends. CDE’s Quant metrics tell us the rest of the story, starting with growth.

CDE earns the highest Quant Growth Grade, an ‘A+’, as well as its No. 1 sector and industry rank, for its stellar forward earnings metrics. Its forward EBITDA Growth of nearly 120% is over 13x the sector median, while its forward EPS growth is over 100%, which is more than 6x the sector. This incredible growth contributes to profitability, particularly in free cash flow, adding to its operational efficiency and future growth. At its Q4 earnings call last week, CEO Mitchell J. Krebs reported record full-year silver and gold production increases, as well as new strategic acquisitions in both metals (SilverCrest and New Gold). Shifting to profitability, Krebs said, "We expect the combined company to generate approximately $3 billion of EBITDA and $2 billion of free cash flow on a full-year run rate basis based on consensus commodity prices from last October."

Coeur’s growing production profile and improving cost structure position it to participate meaningfully in a stronger metals cycle. If capital continues rotating toward commodities as investors navigate trade policy and economic uncertainty, companies with exposure to both gold and silver may see amplified upside. From precious metals, the discussion naturally shifts toward a global platform benefiting from evolving trade dynamics.

3. Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN)

  • Market Capitalization: $2.26T

  • Quant Rating: Strong Buy

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 17 out of 480

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 1 out of 26

  • Sector: Consumer Discretionary

  • Industry: Broadline Retail

Trade policy shifts often force companies to rethink supply chains, and Amazon’s scale as a global e-commerce leader allows it to adapt faster than most competitors. Since the new 15% tariffs may prove to be a net decrease in levies on Chinese imports, Amazon’s margins may get a boost from improved margins that can arise from increased inventory and stronger marketplace activity. Meanwhile, the company’s dominant cloud computing unit, Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a major component of the global AI infrastructure buildout, which continues regardless of short-term macro volatility. In terms of Quant Factors, Amazon’s growth and profitability are its key strengths.

AMZN’s forward EBITDA Growth of 21.74% is more than 380% higher than the sector median’s 4.51% while forward EPS Long Term Growth (3-5Y CAGR) is more than 72% ahead of sector peers. These incredible metrics support AMZN’s stellar free cash flow growth, which can fund its massive capex spending. A frequently maligned metric in today’s financial media, this spending aggressively funds data centers, logistics, and AI infrastructure, investments that have yet to pressure margins and ultimately reinforces its scale advantages and long-term growth trajectory. Speaking of margins, AMZN’s profitability continues to be a strength, earning it an ‘A+’ Growth Factor Grade. Amazon’s $139.41 billion in cash from operations is 430x the sector median and reinforces its ability to fund long-term growth initiatives without relying heavily on external financing, freeing AMZN from a key problem associated with the recent software stock selloff.

Meanwhile, Amazon’s cloud division remains a central pillar of the global AI infrastructure buildout, which continues regardless of short-term geopolitical tensions and tariff-driven macro volatility. That combination of defensive consumer demand and structural technology exposure makes the company uniquely positioned for a complex economic backdrop. The next company sits even deeper inside the technology infrastructure powering this shift.

4. Micron Technology, Inc. (MU)

  • Market Capitalization: $482.84B

  • Quant Rating: Strong Buy

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 2 out of 531

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 1 out of 70

  • Sector: Information Technology

  • Industry: Semiconductor

Another top-performing Alpha Picks stock is Micron Technology, one of the world’s leading producers of DRAM and NAND memory, which are essential components used in everything from smartphones to data centers. In the current policy environment, domestic semiconductor capacity has taken on strategic importance, while the rapid growth of AI workloads is dramatically increasing demand for advanced memory. Each new generation of AI servers requires significantly more high-performance memory, giving suppliers substantial operating leverage during upcycles. From a Quant perspective, MU is a textbook example of how a seemingly overpriced AI stock with incredible performance momentum can continue to defy the expectations of many investors and analysts. How can a stock that has jumped nearly 360% in one year, and almost 50% year-to-date continue to perform? I can start with its Quant Valuation metrics and expand to growth and profitability.

A frequent question I receive from readers of my premium content, as well as Alpha Picks and Pro Quant Portfolio subscribers, is, “How can a stock with an average to poor valuation be a Quant Strong Buy?” The answer often involves the PEG ratio. On the surface, a stock with a share price above $400 and a trailing P/E of 38.03 can appear unattractive to a value investor. But when forward earnings growth has incredible potential, the valuation story flips. For example, MU’s forward P/E of 12.65 offers a 43.7% discount to the technology sector median, and its PEG of 0.22 is nearly an 85% discount to those sector peers. I then naturally turn to the Quant Growth metrics to help support the PEG. MU’s Growth Grade of ‘A+’ is well supported by multiple metrics, including its forward EBITDA growth of over 99%, which is over 6.5x the sector median. Its incredible Levered FCF Growth of over 1600% shows immense profitability, debt capacity, and ability to fund growth internally.

If tariffs and geopolitical friction accelerate investment in domestic technology infrastructure, Micron’s position within the semiconductor industry could become even more valuable. Yet memory is only one piece of the AI hardware puzzle, which leads naturally to another major player in the space.

5. Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD)

  • Market Capitalization: $343.79B

  • Quant Rating: Strong Buy

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 25 out of 531

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 02/26/2026): 5 out of 70

  • Sector: Information Technology

  • Industry: Semiconductors

Advanced Micro Devices designs high-performance processors and accelerators used in personal computers, servers, and artificial intelligence systems. As companies and governments invest heavily in computing infrastructure, demand for advanced computing chips capable of handling AI workloads continues to expand. The policy environment may even reinforce this trend by encouraging domestic production and technological independence. Like MU, AMD’s Quant Strong Buy status is supported by its valuation growth profitability combination.

Like many highly rated AI stocks, AMD’s valuation looks rich on the surface, as its forward P/E of 31.76 represents more than a 41% premium to sector peers. But from a forward PEG perspective, which is more representative of a growth stock, AMD’s 0.66 offers more than a 54% discount to the sector. Turning to the growth metrics supporting AMD’s PEG, AMD’s forward earnings growth, on an EPS GAAP basis, is over 100%, which is more than 6.5x the sector median. This can continue to fuel long-term growth (3-5Y CAGR), which is a healthy 48.48%, nearly 3x the sector median.

AMD has increasingly positioned itself as a high-demand piece of the data center growth engine, helping it to rise above short-term headline pressures. That intersection between policy shifts, economic uncertainty, and innovation ties together the broader investment narrative shaping markets today and the five stocks featured in this article.

Conclusion: Tariffs and Economic Uncertainty Create Opportunities

The evolving tariff landscape is reshaping market leadership in ways that extend well beyond traditional winners and losers. Precious metals miners like Barrick and Coeur can benefit from safe-haven demand fueled by geopolitical tensions and inflation concerns, while global platforms like Amazon may gain from shifting supply chains and resilient consumer activity. At the same time, the relentless expansion of artificial intelligence infrastructure continues to create opportunities in certain semiconductor names like Micron and Advanced Micro Devices. Together, these dynamics illustrate how investors can identify both direct and indirect beneficiaries of policy change. In a market defined by uncertainty yet driven by powerful technological trends, a diversified approach across commodities, platforms, and AI infrastructure may prove especially valuable for investors.

We have many stocks with strong buy recommendations, and you can filter them using Stock Screens to suit your specific investment objectives. Alternatively, Alpha Picks might be ideal if you're interested in two monthly stock picks of the top "strong buy" Quant stocks. Seeking Alpha’s quant ratings and investment research tools help to ensure you are furnished with the best resources to make informed investment decisions while taking the emotion out of investing.

If you’re looking for more frequent investment ideas, we launched the PRO Quant Portfolio in June. It’s a weekly rebalanced selection of our Top 30 Quant Strong Buy stocks, spanning multiple regions and market caps. Happy investing!

data.title: BlackRock Managed Income Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Commentary as of 12/31/25

  • The fund posted returns of 1.37% (Institutional shares)(BLDIX) and 1.21% (Investor A shares, without sales charge)(BLADX) for the fourth quarter of 2025.
  • The fund’s underperformance of its benchmark was driven by a combination of equity security selection and an underweight exposure to international equities. At quarter-end, the fund’s 30-day SEC yield was 5.05% subsidized and 4.81% unsubsidized for institutional shares.
  • The fund increased its emerging market exposure across equities and local-currency debt, and rotated equity positioning by adding global health care and defense-focused stocks. Growth exposure was trimmed in favor of more attractively-valued non-cyclical and defensive segments, alongside a modest tactical increase in the overall equity allocation.

Contributors

Positive performance was led by strong security selection among U.S. equities, as the team’s bespoke allocations were supported by resilient economic data and earnings momentum. The fund’s overweight allocation to equities was additive in a risk-supportive environment. Selection within U.S. investment grade corporate bonds contributed amid stable credit fundamentals, while an overweight position in floating rate assets provided a modest benefit as policy rates remained elevated.

Detractors

The main detractors were an underweight exposure to international equities and weaker security selection in international markets, as improved growth expectations and supportive policy measures drove positive performance outside the United States. Infrastructure equity selection was detrimental, though to a lesser extent, as long-end rate volatility pressured yield-sensitive assets. In addition, the fund’s long Japanese yen position detracted as the currency weakened materially against the U.S. dollar.

Further insight

We continue to expect more attractive opportunities in equities relative to credit, as spreads remain tight and offer limited scope for further compression. Given elevated U.S. equity market concentration, we foresee a broadening of market leadership to support dividend- oriented equities. We maintain an underweight exposure to duration(interest rate sensitivity) as a risk-management measure, amid ongoing long-end rate volatility and uncertainty about the persistence of inflation. Within credit, we continue to favor high- quality investment grade and securitized assets over high yield, where valuations remain stretched. Overall, we expect equity income strategies to remain well supported by resilient earnings growth and a gradual broadening of market participation into 2026.

Institutional shares rated against 80 Us Fund Conservative Allocation Funds, as of 12/31/25, based on risk-adjusted total return. Ratings are determined monthly and subject to change. The Overall Morningstar Rating for a fund is derived from a weighted average of the performance figures associated with its 3-, 5- and 10- year(if applicable) Morningstar Rating metrics.‡

Portfolio management

Justin Christofel, Louis Arranz

Investment approach

The BlackRock Managed Income Fund seeks consistent income in all markets through a diversified, risk-managed approach.

Benchmark

The fund strives to maintain a consistent yield and attractive total return with volatility similar to or less than its risk benchmark. Performance is reviewed on an absolute basis due to the nature of the strategy.

* The fund introduced a performance benchmark of 17.50% MSCI World High Div (Net)/ 60.00% US Agg / 22.50% BBG HY 2% Issuer Capped on April 30, 2025. The attribution is measured on a relative basis against this benchmark.

Expenses for Institutional shares: Total 0.72%; Net, Including Investment Related Expenses (dividend expense, interest expense, acquired fund fees and expenses and certain other fund expenses) 0.47%. For Investor A shares: Total 0.94%; Net, Including Investment Related Expenses 0.72%. Institutional and Investor A shares have contractual waivers with an end date of 06/30/2026 terminable upon 90 days' notice. For certain share classes, BlackRock may voluntarily agree to waive certain fees and expenses in which the adviser may discontinue at any time without notice. Expenses stated as of the fund’s most recent prospectus. Data represents past performance and is no guarantee of future results. Investment returns and principal values may fluctuate so that an investor's shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. All returns assume reinvestment of dividends and capital gains. Current performance may be lower or higher than that shown. Refer to blackrock.com for most recent month-end performance. Investment returns reflect total fund operating expenses, net of all fees, waivers and/or expense reimbursements. Index performance is shown for illustrative purposes only. It is not possible to invest directly in an unmanaged index. Share classes have different sales charges, fees and other features. Returns with sales charge reflect deduction of current maximum initial sales charge of 4% for Investor A shares. Institutional shares have no front- or back-end load. Institutional shares have limited availability and may be purchased at various minimums. See prospectus for details. Net Expenses Excluding Investment Related Expenses for Institutional shares: 0.38%; for Investor A shares: 0.63%. Index returns are for illustrative purposes only. Index performance returns do not reflect any management fees or expenses. Returns for net indices generally assume the reinvestment of dividends after the deduction of the maximum withholding tax in each country applicable to non-residents of the country as determined by the index provider.

Such indices use withholding tax rates that are often at a higher rate than the rates to which the Fund is subject in each country, including for countries where the Fund is not subject to withholding taxes. When this is the case, index performance will be lower than if the index used the Fund’s applicable withholding tax rates, if any. Indexes are unmanaged and one cannot invest directly in an index. Past performance does not guarantee future results.

The Fund s returns prior to October 1, 2016 as reflected in the table are the returns of the Fund when it followed a different investment objective and different investment strategies under the name"BlackRock Investment Grade Bond Portfolio".

Important Risks: The fund is actively managed and its characteristics will vary. Holdings shown should not be deemed as a recommendation to buy or sell securities. Bond values fluctuate in price so the value of your investment can go down depending on market conditions. Fixed income risks include interest-rate and credit risk. Typically, when interest rates rise, there is a corresponding decline in bond values. Credit risk refers to the possibility that the bond issuer will not be able to make principal and interest payments. The fund can invest up to 20% in non-investment-grade debt securities. Non-investment-grade debt securities(high-yield/junk bonds) may be subject to greater market fluc- tuations, risk of default or loss of income and principal than higher-rated securities. The fund may use derivatives to hedge its investments or to seek to enhance returns. Derivatives entail risks relating to liquidity, leverage and credit that may reduce returns and increase volatility.

The opinions expressed are those of the fund’s portfolio management team as of December 31, 2025, and may change as subsequent conditions vary. Information and opinions are derived from proprietary and nonproprietary sources deemed by BlackRock to be reliable, are not necessarily all-inclusive and are not guaranteed as to accuracy.

BlackRock provides compensation in connection with obtaining or using third-party ratings and rankings.

1 The MSCI World High Yield Dividend Index is based on the MSCI World Index, its parent index, and includes large and midcap stocks across 23 Developed Markets(DM) countries. The index is designed to reflect the performance of equities in the parent index(excluding REITs) with higher dividend income and quality characteristics than average dividend yields that are both sustainable and persistent. The Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index is a broad-based flagship benchmark that measures the investment grade, U.S. dollar-denominated, fixed-rate taxable bond market. The Bloomberg U.S. Corporate High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Index— an unmanaged index comprised of issues that meet the following criteria: at least$150 million par value outstanding, maximum credit rating of Ba1, at least one year to maturity, and no one issuer represents more than 2 percent of the index.‡ The Morningstar Rating TM for funds, or "star rating", is calculated for managed products(including mutual funds, variable annuity and variable life subaccounts, exchange-traded funds, closed-end funds, and separate accounts) with at least a three-year history. Exchange-traded funds and open-ended mutual funds are considered a single population for comparative purposes. It is calculated based on a Morningstar Risk-Adjusted Return measure that accounts for variation in a managed product s monthly excess performance, placing more emphasis on downward variations and rewarding consistent performance. The top 10% of products in each product category receive 5 stars, the next 22.5% receive 4 stars, the next 35% receive 3 stars, the next 22.5% receive 2 stars, and the bottom 10% receive 1 star. The Overall Morningstar Rating for a managed product is derived from a weighted average of the performance figures associated with its three-, five-, and 10-year(if applicable) Morningstar Rating metrics. The weights are: 100% three-year rating for 36-59 months of total returns, 60% five-year rating/40% three-year rating for 60-119 months of total returns, and 50% 10-year rating/30% five-year rating/20% three-year rating for 120 or more months of total returns. While the 10-year overall star rating formula seems to give the most weight to the 10-year period, the most recent three-year period actually has the greatest impact because it is included in all three rating periods. The fund was rated against the following numbers of U.S.-domiciled Us Fund Conservative Allocation funds over the following time periods:80 in the last 3 years, 77 in the last 5 years and 58 in the last 10 years. With respect to these Us Fund Conservative Allocation funds, the fund received a Morningstar Rating of 4, 4 and 4 stars for the 3-, 5- and 10-year periods, respectively. Other classes may have different performance characteristics.

You should consider the investment objectives, risks, charges and expenses of the fund carefully before investing. The prospectus and, if available, the summary prospectus contain this and other information about the fund and are available, along with information on other BlackRock funds, by calling 800-882-0052 or from your financial professional. The prospectus should be read carefully before investing.

©2026 BlackRock, Inc. or its affiliates. All Rights Reserved. BLACKROCK is a trademark of BlackRock, Inc. or its affiliates. All other trademarks are those of their respective owners.

Prepared by BlackRock Investments, LLC, member FINRA.

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Trip.com Q4 Earnings: Robust Travel Momentum Silences Regulatory Fears
data.description:
Introduction

For investors unaware, Trip.com (TCOM) is China’s largest online travel agency (OTA) platform, offering accommodation reservations, transportation ticketing, packaged tours, in-destination services, corporate travel management, and other travel-related services in China and internationally. Just for context, Skyscanner is a subsidiary of TCOM.

I remain bullish on Trip.com in 2026, as I view TCOM as the best-of-breed Chinese Internet company, supported by a favourable backdrop of

  1. Robust Chinese inbound travel outlook with strong domestic travelling demand in Chinese New Year
  2. Expanding overseas travel demand in the Asia-Pacific,
  3. AI agent integration driving discovery, transaction and services, alongside
  4. Best-in-class GPM among Chinese Internet peers.

In my opinion, Trip.com’s core competitive advantage lies in its network effect and end-to-end supply chain with over 500,000 commercial partners across 220 countries, spanning 1.7 million hotel properties, more than 600 airlines, and 6,000 car rental suppliers globally, which I believe is something that domestic competitors like Fliggy (BABA), and Meituan fail to compete against.

Furthermore, I believe Trip.com’s strong customer mindshare, in-depth understanding of travellers’ behaviour through decades of transaction data accumulation and bargaining power against domestic commercial suppliers (hotels) for online traffic, positions Trip.com less vulnerable to disruptions from AI agents. In fact, I see AI accelerating Trip.com’s business efficiency rather than jeopardising its moat.

Against the backdrop of share price getting brutally hammered by 30% YTD over concerns over 1) SAMR (State Administration for Market Regulation) investigations, and 2) Competition from Fliggy/Taobao quick commerce /AI agent Qwen (BABA), I believe Trip.com presents an asymmetric Strong Buy at $50, with a forward P/E ratio of 12x.

4Q25 Financial Analysis

Overall, I rate Trip.com’s 4Q25 financials a B+

In 4Q25, aided by resilient travel demand from winter holiday, Trip.com’s net revenue reached RMB 15.4 billion (+21% YoY, -16% QoQ for seasonal factors). 2025. Full-year revenue reached RMB 62.5 billion (+17% YoY)

To slice and die,

  • Accommodation reservation revenue was RMB 6.3 billion (+21% YoY) supported by strong demand for Chinese outbound travel and international hotel bookings.
  • Transportation ticketing revenue was RMB 5.4 billion (+12% YoY) from strong international air bookings.
  • Packaged tour revenue was RMB 1.1 billion (+21% YoY).
  • Corporate travel revenue was RMB 808 million (+15% YoY), driven by more corporate customer wins.

What I dislike during the quarter was Operating Income growing just 11% YoY to RMB 15.8 billion, due to higher marketing expenses (+30% YoY) from international expansion. Net profit was RMB 4.281 billion, which indeed surged 98% YoY, but was skewed by one-time investment income.

Just to pick bones, another thing I dislike was the declining GPM during the quarter, which hit 78.8%, (-2.9ppt QoQ and -0.5ppt YoY) which was the lowest among 2 years.

Nevertheless, compared with other Chinese Internet giants like BABA (40% GPM), JD (16.9% GPM) and Tencent (56% GPM), Trip.com remains a best-of-breed internet pick in China for investors seeking a high-margin goldmine amidst the evolution and subsidies competition in China's local commerce.

Thesis 1: Trip.com’s 2026 growth will be supported by strong inbound travel to China and outbound international travel

I remain bullish about Trip.com’s international pivot.

  • Total bookings on Trip.com's international OTA platform increased by 60% YoY, contributing 40% of total revenue, up from 35% in 2025.

This momentum is expected to continue to accelerate, supported by growing travel in Asia-Pacific (Korea, Thailand, Vietnam, and Hong Kong), driven by rising numbers of Chinese middle-class tourists heading overseas.

Besides, I expect Trip.com to benefit from a strong travelling momentum during the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday (15-23 February), which is the longest in recent years.

Data from the Chinese Ministry of Transport shows that during the CNY holiday, the total number of inter-regional passenger trips exceeded 2.8 billion, averaging 311 million trips per day (+8.2% YoY), setting a new historical record. Daily passenger volume by rail, road, and waterway (+10% YoY), while daily passenger volume by civil aviation (+7.7% YoY).

According to Dragon Trail International and China’s Ministry of Culture and Tourism, Chinese tourists made a total of 596 million domestic trips (+18% YoY) over the CNY holiday (505 million in 2025), hitting a historical high.

For international travel, the National Immigration Authority recorded 9.51 million (+10.2% YoY) border crossings (outbound and inbound) by mainland Chinese citizens during the holiday period.

From a full-year perspective, China Trading Desk estimates that Mainland Chinese travellers will take about 165-175 million cross-border trips (+10% YoY) in 2026, up from 155 million in 2025.

All these data points suggest Trip.com should easily see its topline grow above 15% in 2026, given its market-leading position and above-industry-average growth rate.

As China’s largest OTA commanding a market share of 56% domestically, I believe Trip.com is equally well positioned to benefit from increasing foreign tourists visiting China, which served approximately 20 million inbound travellers throughout the year (+100% YoY), and is expected to double again in 2026.

With China expanding its 30-day Visa-free entry to over 30 countries, including the UK, and Canada starting in February 2026, alongside Europe, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, and Japan etc. I expect growing business and leisure travellers exploring the country.

This benefits Trip.com as an end-to-end OTA travel provider offering one-stop air tickets, domestic hotel accommodation, in-destination tour guide services, and landmark tickets for international tourists, which other domestic vendors (Meituan, Fliggy – low global reputation) or international vendors (Expedia and Booking.com – lacking Chinese exposure) struggle to compete.

Thesis 2: AI agents accelerate rather than disrupt Trip.com business model

There has been a brutal sell-off of OTA platforms (Expedia -28% and Booking Holdings -22%), on the back of "SaaS-pocalypse" over concerns from AI agents’ disruption.

  • For one, investors are worried that personal AI agents (Google's AI search or Microsoft/OpenAI's "Travel GPT") will bypass OTAs and deal directly with hotels and airlines, which could threaten the 10-20% take rate charged by Trip.com/Expedia and Booking.com.
  • For another, investors may worry that AI agents can book itineraries faster and cheaper, displacing traditional OTA platforms.

But I view Trip.com’s core competitive advantage as the transaction and service layer of the travel value chain, alongside its end-to-end global supply chain and commercial partners, including airlines, high-speed rail, hotels, and local activity providers, with live rates globally. I believe it remains implausible and formidable for domestic AI agents like Alibaba’s Qwen or Tencent’s Yuanbao and ByteDance’s Doubao to compete against, as they lack the scale and exclusivity of Trip.com’s commercial partnerships both domestically and globally.

Finally, I believe Trip.com’s strong customer mindshare and in-depth understanding of travellers’ behaviour, built over decades of transaction data accumulation, positions it to leverage AI and Machine Learning to deliver more relevant and actionable travel recommendations and advertisements to users, thereby improving conversion efficiency.

For instance, Trip.com’s proprietary AI tools, such as TripGenie and Trip.Planner offers personalised travel recommendations (itinerary planning and discovery features) leveraging Trip.com’s real-time inventory and pricing. As such, I see AI as an enabler rather than a disruption to Trip.com’s business model.

Thesis 3: Fear of Chinese Regulatory Investigation (SAMR) may be overblown

Investors are concerned about Chinese regulators’ investigation into Trip.com due to “suspected abuse of its dominant market position and monopolistic practices,” including forcing local accommodation merchants to sign exclusive agreements with the platform (by excluding other OTAs like Meituan, Fliggy, and Tongcheng), which limits domestic competition.

Here’s my take on the incident:

Under China’s Anti-Monopoly Law, companies found guilty of monopolistic practices can face fines ranging from 1-10% of their previous year's sales revenue. Referencing SAMR’s investigation into Alibaba (BABA) in 2021, fining the firm a record RMB 18.2 billion ($2.8 billion), this accounted for 3.5-4% of Alibaba’s 2020/2019 total revenue (RMB 509.71/455.71 billion), respectively.

As such, I expect Trip.com to be fined around RMB 2.2-2.5 billion, corresponding to 3.5-4% of Trip.com’s 2025 total revenue (RMB 62.5 billion).

But investors should note that Trip.com currently possesses cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, and a short-term investment of RMB 78.5 billion (USD 11.2 billion), which suggests that the fine will likely be insignificant to the company’s operation and financial health (Just around 3% of the overall company cash balance). As such, I see the fearful narratives from regulatory probes as overextended.

Valuation – Trip.com looks undervalued and highly discounted by the market

Trip.com is trading at a trailing and forward P/E of 8.2/12.7x, respectively, which is cheap relative to the average of 17.1x, and peers (Expedia 11x, Booking.com 15.5x), indicating undervaluation.

A reversion back to its 3-year average of 17.1x and a consensus EPS of $4.5 in 2026 would yield a target price of $76.5/ADR, implying a 45-50% upside.

Conclusion & Risks

Overall, I believe the SAMR regulatory investigation risks and AI agents disruption risks are overextended, and I view Trip.com as an attractive Buy at $50.

I remain bullish about Trip.com’s 1) robust Chinese inbound travel outlook with strong domestic travelling demand in the Chinese New Year, 2) expanding overseas travel demand in Asia-Pacific, 3) AI agent accelerating Trip.com’s value proposition, alongside 4) best-in-class GPM among Chinese Internet peers.

I do acknowledge Reddit’s risks include 1) regulatory overhang from SAMR, 2) Competition from Meituan, Alibaba and ByteDance’s AI agent and domestic travel pivot, alongside 3) sluggish domestic consumption sentiment, which will weigh on stock multiples.

I still firmly believe that Trip.com remain attractively priced at a forward P/E of 12x, with an expected upside of +50%.

data.title: Everpure: Buy The Dip On Price Increases And Hyperscaler Expansion
data.description:
So far in 2026, the major theme that has unraveled the stock markets and decimated a years-long tech rally is the idea of a “SaaSpocalypse,” or the notion that agentic AI will wipe out existing enterprise software stocks. Investors, meanwhile, have fled to the safety of infrastructure companies that are providing the backend IT services necessary to run AI and inference models.

Against this backdrop, Pure Storage, now rebranded as Everpure (PSTG), has seen more optimism from the markets as it shifts from becoming a more commoditized data storage provider to a strategic supplier for hyperscalers and AI companies. However, the stock just fell 10% after reporting strong Q4 results (despite an initially positive earnings reaction) and unveiling an aggressive plan for continued market share grab in 2026.

I last wrote a buy article on Everpure in December, when the stock had fallen to the ~$80s after a poorly received Q3 earnings print. Since then, Everpure has made some critical business model changes that I think will position the company well for continued growth and margin expansion this year. Amid a share price that remains down from TTM highs just shy of $100 (notched briefly in October), I reiterate my buy rating here.

As a reminder, Everpure's core business is selling "storage as a service," which it's now increasingly rebranding as data management. The company essentially makes it easy for companies to offload their IT backend storage needs to Everpure, which sells integrated hardware servers and software tools to manage storage needs. Increasingly, more of the company's sales are going to hyperscaler cloud companies, which have an insatiable demand for new data center capacity.

Since last quarter, a lot has changed fundamentally for this company beyond just a corporate name rebrand (which is intended to reduce the company’s association with storage, which was initially an oversupplied commodity, and move toward data management as a strategic value-add). To me, these are all changes that position the company well for earnings growth.

First: Everpure raised its prices on February 9. The company had initially delayed price increases to try to prioritize share growth, but amid rising component prices, the company is making the decision to protect margins. We think this is a good environment for a price increase, since customers are now well aware of the memory shortage and prepared to lock in higher prices in order to secure supply. Speaking to the price bump on the Q4 earnings call, CEO Charlie Giancarlo noted as follows:

Everpure raised prices on our product line on February 9th reflecting the dramatic and rapid rise in component prices. I believe we were the last in our industry to raise prices, and I also believe that our increase was the lowest in the industry, to protect our customers. Based on the extraordinary rapid rise in component costs, we expect product gross margins in Q1 to be at the lower end of our typical range of 65-70%.”

A major reason Everpure’s stock has wavered over the past year is scrutiny over the company’s weakening gross margin profile (though we note that for a company previously considered a commodity, a mid-60s margin isn’t at all disappointing). This move to right-size prices is a tailwind to revenue growth and will help in the profit margin rebound.

The other move that Everpure is making (which perhaps Wall Street is cheering more) is that going forward, it will no longer be securing NAND supply on behalf of its hyperscaler customers (such as Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT), which are the leading capex spenders in the AI boom), which, needless to say, is becoming an increasingly sizable chunk of Everpure’s business. This reduces Everpure’s exposure to volatile prices, with hyperscalers owning supply procurement agreements with major suppliers like Micron (MU), which are constrained through the visible future.

In spite of the recent upswing in growth and strong actions to protect the company’s margins, Everpure still trades at very reasonable valuations against forward expectations. At current post-earnings share prices near $66, Everpure trades at a market cap of $21.78 billion. Netting off the $1.55 billion of cash (which is now completely debt free) from Everpure’s latest balance sheet gives us an enterprise value of $20.23 billion.

For FY27 (the year for Everpure ending in January 2027), the company is guiding to $4.30-$4.40 billion in revenue, or 17-20% y/y growth. It’s expecting particularly robust Q1 revenue growth of 27-30% y/y, a sharp acceleration from 20% growth in Q4. Management is also expecting a midpoint ~26% growth in pro forma operating income to ~$800 million, or an 18.4% midpoint margin that’s up 110 bps y/y - a relief for investors who had worried about possible margin compression amid rising component costs and a statement to the benefits of the company’s recent price increases and passing on NAND procurement burden to customers. If we assume FCF grows at the same 26% y/y pace as operating income (a conservative assumption, given that Everpure will be procuring fewer commodities in FY27 versus FY26 and thus has less inventory burden), FY27 FCF would be $776 million.

This positions Everpure’s valuation multiples at:

  • 4.6x EV/FY27 revenue
  • 25.3x EV/FY27 FCF

Of course, this isn’t a bargain stock (for bargains, look to the adjacent enterprise software sector). What we’re trading in lieu of a discount, however, is high quality growth. The company has clear commitments from hyperscalers that are fueling huge RPO growth at a recovering gross margin and proven profitability.

Amid a multiyear AI capex investment cycle, Everpure remains a “growth at a reasonable price” stock that remains well off 52-week highs. Stay long here and use the recent, nonsensical dip as a buying opportunity.

Q4 Download

Let’s now go through Everpure’s latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Everpure’s revenue grew 20% y/y to $1.06 billion, smashing Wall Street expectations of $1.03 billion (+17% y/y) by a three point margin. Also, revenue growth accelerated meaningfully from 16% growth in Q3 and is expected to continue accelerating to a stunning 27-30% range in Q1. All of these are healthy indicators that AI is providing a true, durable tailwind for Everpure’s business.

One of the core metrics we’re looking at that further crystallizes the rampant nature of the current demand for storage products is Everpure’s RPO, or essentially backlog. RPO in the fourth quarter surged 40% y/y to $3.67 billion, adding $728 million in net new backlog in this quarter alone.

Speaking to momentum on sales to hyperscalers and the NAND procurement change on the Q4 earnings call, CFO Tarek Robbiati noted as follows:

First and foremost, and specifically for our hyperscaler business, I would like to remind everyone that we started ramping our hyperscaler line of business in fiscal year '26 and feel very confident about the future of our business for years to come. We expect to significantly accelerate shipments and revenues in fiscal year '27 relative to fiscal year '26. This momentum is reflected in our strong fiscal year '27 guidance. As a reminder, hyperscaler revenues are governed by the schedule of hyperscalers data center buildouts and are not linear during the course of the year.

For fiscal year '27, we expect the majority of revenue from hyperscalers to be recognized in Q3 and Q4. Also, we have now standardized our business model to cater for the hyperscaler market. Moving forward, we will procure some of the components that are needed by hyperscalers to build their solution in their environment, but not the NAND. Hyperscalers will continue to procure the NAND through their supply chain. As a result, we expect gross margins of hyperscaler revenues to range between 75% to 85%, a level accretive to product revenue gross margins and overall company gross margins."

The company notes additionally that another factor driving strong sales is that Everpure has broadened its storage options, ranging from higher performance (and higher cost) to lower-cost storage for less-critical workloads. It’s now becoming more of a one-stop shop for a company needing data management and storage for multiple workstreams, boosting the company’s potential wallet share.

On the profitability front, as expected, the company's product gross margins slid sequentially to 67.3% (though still improved on a y/y basis). Meanwhile, total gross margins still rose y/y to 71.4%, helped by richer subscription margins. We expect the company's price increases to help stabilize product margins into FY27.

Stacked on top of strong opex discipline, the company also achieved 100 bps of sequential operating margin improvement to 21.3% (also a ~4 point y/y rise):

Pro forma EPS of $0.69 also beat Street expectations of $0.64 with 8% upside.

Risks and Key Takeaways

Of course, there are a number of risks that we need to keep in mind here as well. At some point, hyperscaler capex will peak (2026 could very well be the peak year for datacenter investments, as Meta and Microsoft are under market pressure to show returns on AI spending). Present levels of demand may taper off, and Everpure will be pressured to find other sources of net-new business. We note as well that while Pure Storage is no longer committing to procuring NAND on behalf of its customers, it still is procuring other key components - any of which could become the bottleneck in the datacenter supply chain.

That said, I see more upside than risk in this stock. Everpure remains on track for a big year in FY27. Unprecedented demand from hyperscalers is fueling expectations for sharp revenue acceleration in Q1, while the company is also turning more structurally profitable thanks to its recent February price increases as well as passing on the burden of NAND price volatility to its hyperscaler partners. Stay long here and use the post-earnings dip as a buying opportunity.

data.title: Chart Of The Day: Mortgages Take Out 6%, Helping The Housing Sector
data.description:
By Mike Larson

The benchmark 30-year fixed mortgage rate just broke below the 6% threshold. That could break the housing market logjam - putting one of my favorite “Sleeper Sectors” for 2026 firmly in focus!

Take a look at the MoneyShow Chart of the Day. It shows the average 30-year home loan rate from Freddie Mac, which has been tracking the data since 1971. You can see it dipped to 5.98% this week, the first time that’s happened since September 2022.

(Source: Freddie Mac)

Why does that matter? The housing market has been caught in a state of stasis. Owners who locked in ultra-low rates in the 2s, 3s, or 4s have been reluctant to give up those cheap loans by selling. Buyers have been reluctant to buy because rates in the 6s and 7s have made monthly payments too high. As a result, home listings, sales, and pricing have remained weak for a few years.

But as I noted several weeks ago, lower rates could break the logjam! Taking out a big, round number will also get the attention of buyers and sellers - especially since it’s being widely reported in the press.

The two housing ETFs I wrote about last month are trouncing the State Street SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) so far in 2026. The State Street SPDR S&P Homebuilders ETF (XHB) is up 10.8% year-to-date, while the iShares US Home Construction ETF (ITB) is up 10.5%. That compares to just 1.6% for SPY.

If mortgage rates continue on their current trajectory, that outperformance could be just the beginning. And in a year where rotation is the name of the game, home building, real estate, and construction stocks could be just what your portfolio needs to pile up more profits!

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

Originally published on MoneyShow.com

data.title: French Inflation Rebounds In February But Remains Contained
data.description:
By Charlotte de Montpellier, Senior Economist, France and Switzerland

Inflation rises, but solely due to energy

As expected, French inflation increased in February, reaching 1.0% (1.1% for the harmonised index), up from 0.3% in January (0.4% harmonised). Although the figures are slightly higher than the consensus forecast, this rise was expected on our side: it is mainly explained by less favourable base effects. In February 2025, regulated gas tariffs had been cut by 15% following a government decision. That decrease has now dropped out of the price index calculation, as regulated gas tariffs have since remained stable. This mechanically contributes to the rise in the inflation rate. In addition, energy prices on global markets have edged up slightly. Overall, energy inflation is now down only 3% year-on-year, compared with a 7.6% fall in January.

Beyond these energy-related base effects, inflationary pressures remain moderate. Services inflation is still contained at 1.8% year-on-year, following 1.7% in January, whereas Insee was still expecting a rate close to 2% for February in its December forecast. This moderation in services prices helps to limit the overall increase in inflation. Prices of manufactured goods are falling year-on-year (-0.3%), but the decline is less pronounced than in January (-1.2%), notably due to a different timing of the sales period.

In the coming months, a further small rise in headline inflation is likely, as energy base effects gradually become less favourable. Energy inflation should therefore move back into positive territory. This does not, however, signal a marked resurgence in inflationary pressures. On the contrary, inflation in France should remain subdued in the months ahead and fluctuate within a range of 1% to 1.5%. France should therefore continue to be among the countries with the lowest inflation rates in the euro area.

The labour market lacks momentum

In addition, Insee today published employment data for the fourth quarter of 2025, showing a slight decline in salaried employment (-0.1% quarter on quarter, i.e., 40,100 jobs lost), following stability in the third quarter. Salaried employment is now down 0.2% year-on-year (-45,900 jobs), while remaining well above its pre-pandemic level (+4.9%, or +1.3 million jobs). Data on self-employment, which is generally more dynamic, has not yet been published.

Overall, the French labour market therefore remains relatively resilient, with limited job losses. Nevertheless, the lack of momentum is evident, and the likelihood of a turnaround with strongly positive net job creation remains low in the coming months. The employment climate, as measured by the Insee survey, deteriorated further in February, with business leaders showing increased caution regarding hiring. It is therefore likely that France will continue to record slight job losses in the coming months, even though we do not expect a collapse in the labour market.

Overall, economic growth should remain positive but moderate in the absence of a genuine short-term growth driver. We are forecasting GDP growth of 1.0% in 2026, after 0.9% in 2025.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: Northern High Yield Fixed Income Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
For most of the final quarter of 2025, the macroeconomic landscape was shaped as much by what investors couldn’t see as by what they could. The U.S. government shutdown—lasting a record 43 days—created a significant information vacuum just as markets sought clarity on growth, inflation, and policy trajectories. Despite the data fog, the global macro backdrop proved “good enough” for risk assets. Global growth held firm, inflation stayed sticky but avoided more disruptive outcomes, and most central banks leaned more accommodative than hawkish. In the U.S., elevated downside labor market risk kept U.S. Federal Reserve (“Fed”) easing in play, leading to rate cuts even as the economy expanded. However, policymaker dissents emerged as the Fed Funds rate approached the Federal Open Market Committee’s neutral estimate. International markets—particularly Japan and parts of Europe—offered broadly supportive signals, though political uncertainty occasionally weighed on European sentiment. Since mid-2024, most major developed market central banks have cut rates by 150-200 basis points (1.50%-2.00%) or more, meaning some could be close to the end of their easing cycle. The Bank of Japan remains on a separate trajectory with a gradual pace of rate hikes from a highly accommodative starting point, including two in 2025 and two more expected in 2026. Overall, the global tariff environment proved less disruptive than earlier fears. U.S. monthly tariff collections rose but remained well below levels implied by announced policies, while statutory rates edged lower as deals and exemptions took hold. Still, investors monitored persistent trade-related risks alongside other potential headwinds, including slower AI investment, labor market softening, bond market volatility tied to inflation or fiscal stress, and ongoing risk of geopolitical shocks.

Financial markets capped a strong 2025 with 4Q gains across both equities and fixed income. Many fixed income segments gained around 1%. The Treasury yield curve steepened as short-end rates dropped following multiple rate cuts in the quarter by the U.S. Federal Reserve. Credit spreads were mostly unchanged in both investment grade and high yield, ending near their lowest levels in 2025. Global equities added a little more than 3% as non-U.S. regions outperformed the U.S. in U.S. dollar terms (despite slight U.S. dollar strengthening). U.S. equity returns were positive (roughly 2.5%).

The U.S. Federal Reserve continued easing, delivering 25-basis point (0.25%) cuts at each of its two meetings. However, an increase in hawkish dissents and adjustments to the policy statement signaled a higher threshold for future reductions. Even so, ongoing easing contributed to further steepening of the Treasury curve, as front-end yields through five years moved lower. The 2‑ year yield ended the quarter at 3.47%, down 14 basis points (0.14%). In contrast, longer-term rates remained more resilient, with the 10-year yield up 2 basis points (0.02%) to 4.17%.

Investment grade (IG) credit spreads widened by 3 basis points (0.03%) to 0.73%, while high-yield (HY) spreads tightened by 1 basis point (0.01%) to 2.66%. In terms of return, IG fixed income gained 1.1%, with high yield slightly outperforming at 1.3%. Periods of short-lived weakness followed by a strong recovery mirrored the pattern seen throughout most of the year. As a result, credit spreads enter 2026 below where they began 2025 across many quality buckets. Fundamentals continue to look healthy, but AI-related capex is helping to accelerate corporate debt issuance.

Explanation of Results

High Yield Fixed Income had positive performance October through December, adding to an already positive year. The broad High Yield index returned 131 basis points (1.31%) for the quarter, ending the year up 8.62% as measured by the Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Issuer Capped 2% Index. Healthcare and Finance Companies led sector performance over the final quarter of 2025. Healthcare benefitted from positive earnings and sector rotation as the market sought quality while interest rate cuts from the U.S. Federal Reserve and steepening of the yield curve helped Finance Companies. Packaging and Railroads lagged sector performance over the quarter. Packaging underperformed on concerns about some of the more highly leveraged issuers addressing upcoming maturities while softening freight volumes and high fixed costs negatively affected Railroads.

High Yield recorded positive inflows October through December with $3.8 billion entering the asset class (Source: Lipper). The primary market issued $65 billion over the quarter, capping a very busy year as $331 billion was issued throughout 2025, the busiest year since 2021 ($469 billion) (Source: Barclays). Companies have taken advantage of market strength to proactively address funding needs. We view this as a positive to underlying fundamentals for our market.

The fund outperformed its benchmark. An overweight to CCC rated bonds helped performance while an underweight to BB rated bonds was a detractor. An overweight to Independent Energy was a positive while overweighting Midstream lessened performance. Security selection within Media & Entertainment and Healthcare was beneficial to performance while security selection within Cable & Satellite and Utilities and Consumer Cyclical Services detracted.

Holdings are subject to change and current and future portfolio holdings are subject to risk.

Performance as of 12/31/2025

1 Bloomberg U.S. Corporate High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Index is an unmanaged index that measures the market of U.S. dollar-denominated, non-investment grade, fixed-rate, taxable corporate bonds. It is a version of the Bloomberg High Yield Corporate Bond Index except it limits its exposure of each issuer to 2% of the total market value and redistributes any excess market value Index-wide on a pro-rata basis. It is not possible to invest directly in an index.*High Yield Index: Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Total Return Index. The Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Bond Index measures the USD-denominated, high yield, fixed-rate corporate bond market. Securities are classified as high yield if the middle rating of Moody's, Fitch and S&P is Ba1/BB+/BB+ or below.

Performance quoted represents past performance and does not guarantee future results. Investment return and principal value will fluctuate so that shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Current performance may be lower or higher than that shown here. Performance data current to the most recent month end is available by calling 800-595-9111.

The Gross and Net Expense Ratios are as of the most recent prospectus. The Net Expense Ratio includes contractual expense reimbursements that, if not extended, will end on July 31, 2026.

Bond Risk: Bond funds will tend to experience smaller fluctuations in value than stock funds. However, investors in any bond fund should anticipate fluctuations in price, especially for longer-term issues and in environments of rising interest rates.

Defaulted Bond Risk: The risk that the inability or unwillingness of an issuer or guarantor of a fixed-income security to meet its payment or other financial obligations will adversely affect the value of the Fund’s investments and its returns. Changes in the credit rating of a debt security held by the Fund could have a similar effect.

High-Yield Risk: The risk that the Fund’s below-investment grade fixed-income securities, sometimes known as “junk bonds,” will be subject to greater credit risk, price volatility and risk of loss than investment grade securities, which can adversely impact the Fund’s return and NAV. High yield securities are considered highly speculative and are subject to the increased risk of an issuer’s inability to make principal and interest payments.

Municipal Bond Risk: Debt securities issued by state or local governments may be subject to special political, legal, economic and market factors that can have a significant effect on the portfolio's yield or value.

Sector Risk: The risk that companies in similar businesses may be similarly affected by particular economic or market events, which may, in certain circumstances, cause the value of securities of all companies in a particular sector of the market to decrease.

Not FDIC insured | May lose value | No bank guarantee

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Innovative Industrial Properties: Cannabis REIT At Risk Premium (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Innovative Industrial Properties (IIPR) just released Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings. With tenant defaults in 2025 and cannabis rescheduling uncertain, the share price remains depressed, but I think the valuation is finally attractive.

Summary of Previous Thesis

The first time I covered this company was almost two years ago, in May 2024. At the time, IIPR was still a cannabis pure play, by way of its REIT structure. General sentiment about cannabis at that time was positive, but I declined to rate their shares a Buy. I did acknowledge the positives that came with this investment:

  • Listing on a major exchange, rare for any cannabis company
  • First mover as a cannabis REIT
  • Steady profits
  • Low-risk, triple-net leasing model
  • Virtually zero debt

I largely felt that IIPR lacked room for growth, with much of the cannabis market developed at that time. I wrote:

Cannabis continues to be a popular search among stocks for outsized returns on waves of legalization. With IIP, a honeymoon of vertical growth rates seems to be behind it, and there are no obvious catalysts to this company taking off. Rather, it will be a game of managing the current portfolio and working with tenants to improve the properties, while incrementally adding new tenants as more layers of legalization come down and bring more growth into the industry.

It just didn't seem discounted for what seemed likely to be slower growth ahead, hence my Hold rating.

Strategic Adjustment

Cannabis investing depends heavily on politics. Former optimism hinged on the Biden Administration's intentions to reschedule cannabis as a Schedule III substance under the Controlled Substances Act. This would pose enormous tax benefits, improving the cash flow for tenants across IIPR's portfolio.

Biden's exit from the 2024 election and Harris's defeat created much more uncertainty on this, and previous rescheduling efforts halted under Trump. Cyclical factors, such as oversupply and upcoming debt maturities, weakened many operators. IIPR therefore announced a strategic pivot in August 2025. They would be diversifying into life sciences, not longer purely owning and acquiring cannabis properties.

It indicated the limited growth available to cannabis that I worried was present. Management finally seemed to concur and acted accordingly. Unlike their cannabis portfolio, which consists of directly owned assets, the shift into life sciences is done through investment in IQHQ, Inc., a life sciences real estate platform. The two primary investment vehicles entail:

  • Providing a $100M credit facility at 13.5% interest
  • Purchase of $170M of IQHQ's preferred stock at a 15% yield
  • (Thirdly, conditional warrants to buy equity in IQHQ)

Put in simple terms, IIPR is acting as equity REIT in cannabis and mortgage REIT in life sciences with this shift.

Full-Year 2025 Results

The full-year results and latest Form 10K illustrate the issues that hit IIPR's portfolio. The first and most obvious is the impact to the top line.

Annual revenue, which had cleared $300M in 2023 and 2024 fell to $266M in 2025. In their MD&A section, management explained:

The decrease was primarily driven by tenant defaults, resulting in a decrease of $46.9 million related to properties leased to PharmaCann, Gold Flora, TILT, and 4Front.

The cash flow statement, however, shows some subtle changes between 2024's and 2025's results.

Common share distributions remained steady in 2025, in spite of this sharp stress on the portfolio. Moreover, IIPR went from some share issuance in 2024 to some buybacks in 2025. The move into life sciences also allowed them access to a credit facility on a balance sheet that was nearly free of debt before.

The balance sheet shows total assets remaining relatively steady, around $2.3B, with $290M in notes due this year. The $102M credit facility to support the life sciences segment is also apparent. That the reported assets did not grow with the contribution of the credit facility is not, as one might think, primarily a consequence of realized losses or asset impairments. The income statement shows that normal depreciation and amortization accounted for this.

Coming into 2026, IIPR is still primarily a cannabis REIT, but life sciences became 6.6% of its portfolio in less than a year. It is still primarily a REIT and business exposed to the strengths and weakness of cannabis.

Outlook and Valuation

When I wrote about IIPR the first time, it was valued $107 per share, had market cap over $3B, and a dividend yield of about 6.5%. Now, it's $53, has a market cap of $1.4B, and dividend yield of 14.8%. Just on valuation alone, it's a very different prospect, but we still need to assess if it's a good price, taking into account the changed fundamentals and the outlook they support.

First, how sustainable in the $7.60 annual dividend? Let's look at how IIPR breaks down its FFO, normalized FFO, and adjusted FFO.

We see that FFO removes changes related to asset values, NFFO removes one-off cash items, and AFFO removes some other non-cash expenses. AFFO is one of management's preferred measures of financial performance, as it's indicative of the cash flow to support the dividend based on a long-term, recurring state of the business.

No measure of FFO per share in 2025, even AFFO at $7.24, is sufficient to cover the current dividend.

Even just focusing on Q4, which has the full benefits of the move into life sciences, and annualizing it is insufficient. During the earnings call, Executive Chairman Alan Gold gave positive outlook on the dividend but fell short of confirming coverage:

Well, I think, first of all, the dividend -- our dividend policy is set by our Board, and they review what has occurred in the past and the projections going forward. But what we're seeing is this return to growth, and we're seeing strong re-leasing activity, which is driving revenues. And we continue to see -- and we have the resolutions of some of these major lease or major litigations. And with those resolutions and the activity -- the leasing activity we're seeing, we continuously feel positive about where we are with regards to our dividend.

It's very plausible that the dividend could be trimmed a bit (perhaps as low as $7.00) if upcoming quarters have enough non-recurring cash expenses. Even so, that's still about a 13% yield on cost, giving IIPR something of a risk premium.

An example of non-recurring cash items may include refinancing the 2026 notes, which come due this May. In the Form 10K, management stated:

As of December 31, 2025, the outstanding principal balance on our Notes due 2026 was $291.2 million and we plan to refinance these notes prior to maturity in May 2026.

No announcement has been made, but the Form 10K also mentions that these notes were issued in 2021, when interest rates were much lower and when IIPR was given an investment-grade credit rating. The rating is intact, but interest rates are up.

Assuming another five-year issue, the 5Y Note (US5Y) rose from about 0.80% to 3.63%, more recently. As the 2026 notes bear 5.5% interest, it's conceivable they would need to be refinanced at 8%. With a $291M balance, that would be a $7.2M annual difference, plus a few million related to underwriting and repurchasing the old notes. With AFFO already too low at $205M for 2025, this friction doesn't help. The concern isn't in ability to refinance, so much as it is the higher cost of capital going forward.

Overall, I am less worried about the durability of their cannabis portfolio than before. This is because President Trump announced in December, for the first time, that he was committed to rescheduling cannabis to Schedule III. While the long-term pacing of this is still unclear, it bodes well for these assets, whose tenants have been in a cyclical rut.

This improvement, plus the substantially lower valuation (14.8% dividend, 7x AFFO multiple), make IIPR worth upgrading to Buy. Nevertheless, let's keep in mind a major risk factor, besides any implicit to a dividend trim.

Several of their major tenants have significant debt and questionable cash flow to repay it:

  • Ascend Wellness Holdings (AAWH)
  • Curaleaf (CURLF)
  • Cannabit (CBSTF)
  • 4Front (FFNTF) (This is in receivership)
  • Cresco (CRLBF)

These are five that have publicly available financial data and account for 36.1% of the portfolio's ABR. If they all become distressed, then IIPR would have to worry about more than a trimmed dividend. Depending on how soon Trump reschedules cannabis, many of these companies could end up in a similar spot as 4Front, leading to defaults and lack of payments.

IIPR can find new tenants among better-capitalized operators in the industry, but this would take time, possibly eliminating the dividend in the meantime.

Conclusion

The risk to IIPR's cannabis properties still loom and have, in part, materialized. The high-yield investments in life sciences, unexpected tailwinds from rescheduling under Trump, and heavily reduced valuation, however, make the shares more attractive than before. With the dividend now more properly representing a risk premium, I upgrade IIPR to Buy.

data.title: German Labour Market Sends Mixed Messages In February
data.description:
By Carsten Brzeski, Global Head of Macro

German unemployment dropped by 14,700 in February, the best February performance of the labour market since 2022. At the same time, however, the fact that the absolute number of those unemployed remains above the politically important 3 million is anything but good news. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.3%.

No turning point in sight yet

Over the last four years, German unemployment has increased by some 500,000. This gradual worsening reflects textbook economics; with the economy effectively stagnating for more than five years and industry facing severe structural challenges, a deterioration in the labour market was inevitable. At the same time, employment has started to gradually drop since last summer, providing additional evidence of a structurally changing labour market: a shrinking working force due to demographics, sectoral and geographical shifts due to the industrial transition and higher entrance barriers for graduates due to AI.

Looking ahead, the number of vacancies has come down further and even if employment plans in both manufacturing and services have started to rebound, we see the gradual worsening of the labour market continuing throughout the year. Previous and potential additional announcements of cost-cutting measures across the automotive and other industries as well as the continuing increase in bankruptcies suggest that conditions will first worsen before they improve. The AI disruption of the labour market could add to this. If we are right and the cyclical recovery of the German economy unfolds over the coming months, the labour market, however, should stabilise towards the end of the year.

All in all, today's labour market report sends a mixed message but definitely no signs of a turning point. Instead, the gradual worsening looks set to continue.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: Ashtead: A Great Business But Fairly Valued (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
My last piece on Ashtead (ASHTF) was my June “buy” piece, Ashtead: Lots Still To Look Forward To. Since its publication, the Ashtead share price has moved up 23%. (Since that piece was published, as part of ongoing portfolio reallocation, I have sold my stake in Ashtead).

With its primary listing due to move to New York next month, alongside plans to host an investor day in the city, now seems like an apposite time to provide a snapshot of the company’s health.

The Basic Investment Thesis

In June, and previous pieces, I set out what I see as the investment thesis.

Plant rental is a large market and one that benefits from some attractive economic characteristics. Demand can often be high, contracts can stretch for months or years, specialist requirements can make some customers effectively captives. Ashtead has rolled up lots of smaller businesses over the years and also taken a strategic approach to business building. That has given it economies of scale and attractive profitability.

One ongoing risk, though, is the inherently cyclical nature of plant rental. As the economy weakens and construction activity reduces, rental providers like Ashtead can be left holding the baby in terms of having lots of capital tied up in pricy plant that lies idle.

What sets Ashtead apart from many rivals, in my view, is how strategic it has been about growing the business, through a series of strategic growth plans. In my prior piece, I reckoned that Ashtead was undervalued given its proven business model and North American focus.

Current Financial Year Shows Modest Revenue Growth but Reduced Profitability

In December, the company released its results for the first half of its current financial year. These were fine at the top line, though less impressive at the bottom line.

Revenues rose 1% year-on-year, but a 9% decline in operating profit fed through to a 10% fall in pre-tax profit. Revenue performance was the same across both the first and second quarter, but those profit metrics were both sequentially worse in the second quarter.

The company struck an upbeat note about current demand, saying that it continued to see “positive leading indicators for local non-residential construction activity”. It also launched a new $1.5bn share buyback, which I see as a strong sign of management confidence coming hot on the heels of $714m of buybacks in the first half.

For the full year, the company is guiding for rental revenue growth of 0%-4%, and free cash flow of $2.2bn-$2.5bn. That compares favourably to last year’s free cash inflow of $1.8bn.

Can Ashtead Step Up a Gear?

Over the long run, Ashtead has performed phenomenally well. It is up 6,410% since the start of 2010, for example.

But the current outlook feels more like “steady as she goes” rather than transformative to the investment case. Meanwhile, an uncertain outlook for the U.S. economy and therefore for the construction market in general (and the plant rental market within it specifically) poses a risk to revenues and profits over the coming years.

I have outlined in previous pieces on the name that the company’s strategic plans have helped it perform very well in the past and I expect the same of its current plan (Sunbelt 4.0). Indeed, in its interim results the company specifically noted, “As we execute on Sunbelt 4.0, we expect a number of years of strong earnings and free cash flow generation”. Ashtead’s free cash flow generation is substantial and I do think it has the potential to keep that flowing if the construction market holds up. As it points out, having invested heavily in infrastructure under its previous strategic plan, it is now trying to make the most of that infrastructure to generate revenues and, thereby, cash flow.

But while I like the business, see it as very well run and also appreciate the financial potential of Sunbelt 4.0, I do not see transformational growth drivers in the coming year or two. The fact that the year’s outlook for rental revenue has at its bottom end a flat year-on-year performance underlines that point I feel.

Valuation Does Not Now Look Compelling

Currently Ashtead’s price-to-earnings ratio is 22, which is a bit steeper than I would like to find it attractive.

At the interim point, net debt was $10.5bn. The current market cap is $29.7bn, making for an enterprise value of $40.2bn. Last year’s cash flow from operating activities was $2.2bn. I expect this year’s may be higher given the company’s guidance on cash flow overall, but using last year’s number, the current enterprise value is around 18 times operating cash flow. Again, I do not find that especially attractive but I do at least think it is justifiable for a proven company with ongoing growth potential.

I expect the switch to a primary listing in New York City to give the share price some benefit as it will help it to access deeper liquidity more easily, in an end market that anyway accounts for most of its business.

Still, as outlined above, I see current share price as reasonable rather than attractive to start a position and accordingly, on valuation grounds, am downgrading my rating from “buy” to “hold”.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
